2026-01-23.content: * Applied patch for [SPARK-48292](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-48292) in Serverless for Apache Spark [1.2](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc-serverless/docs/concepts/versions/spark-runtime-1.2) and [2.2](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc-serverless/docs/concepts/versions/spark-runtime-2.2) runtimes.

summary.title: Spark Runtime Fix
summary.summary: A fix for SPARK-48292 has been applied to Serverless for Apache Spark runtimes 1.2 and 2.2. This resolves an issue within the Spark environment.

summary.title: New Apache Spark runtimes available
summary.summary: We're excited to announce the release of new Serverless for Apache Spark runtime versions, including 1.2.67, 2.2.67, 2.3.20, and 3.0.3. These updates provide the latest features and performance improvements for your Spark workloads.

2026-01-13.content:
**Dataproc on Compute Engine:** The following subminor image versions announced on [January 06, 2026](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/release-notes#January_06_2026) have been rolled back:

* 2.0.156-debian10, 2.0.156-ubuntu18, 2.0.156-rocky8

summary.title: Dataproc image versions rolled back
summary.summary: Certain Dataproc on Compute Engine image versions released on January 06, 2026 have been rolled back due to an issue. This affects multiple versions across Debian, Ubuntu, and Rocky Linux operating systems. Users are advised to check the release notes for specific details and potential impact.

summary.title: New Spark Runtime Versions Available
summary.summary: We are announcing the release of new serverless for Apache Spark runtime versions. These include updates for versions 1.2, 2.2, 2.3, and 3.0. Check the documentation for details on each specific version.

2026-01-06.content: Removed use of deprecated Hadoop configuration properties `fs.default.name` and `yarn.resourcemanager.system-metrics-publisher.enabled`.

summary.title: Deprecated Hadoop properties removed
summary.summary: We have removed the use of deprecated Hadoop configuration properties, specifically `fs.default.name` and `yarn.resourcemanager.system-metrics-publisher.enabled`. This change ensures we are using current and supported configurations.

2026-01-06.content:
New [Dataproc on Compute Engine subminor image versions](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/versioning/dataproc-version-clusters#supported-dataproc-image-versions):

* 2.0.156-debian10, 2.0.156-ubuntu18, 2.0.156-rocky8
* 2.1.105-debian11, 2.1.105-ubuntu20, 2.1.105-ubuntu20-arm, 2.1.105-rocky8
* 2.2.73-debian12, 2.2.73-ubuntu22, 2.2.73-ubuntu22-arm, 2.2.73-rocky9
* 2.3.20-debian12, 2.3.20-ml-ubuntu22, 2.3.20-rocky9, 2.3.20-ubuntu22, 2.3.20-ubuntu22-arm

**Rollback Notice:** These image versions were rolled back on [January 13, 2026](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/release-notes#January_13_2026).

summary.title: Dataproc image version updates
summary.summary: New image versions for Dataproc on Compute Engine are now available, offering updated components and features. These updates include various Debian, Ubuntu, and Rocky Linux distributions across multiple Dataproc versions. Please note that these specific image versions were rolled back on January 13, 2026.

2026-01-06.content: Fixed the `spark.driver.extraClassPath` delimiter for the Jupyter SparkMonitor Listener.

summary.title: Spark Monitor Listener Fix
summary.summary: Resolved an issue with the Spark Monitor Listener's `spark.driver.extraClassPath` delimiter. This correction ensures proper functionality for users employing this feature.

2026-01-06.content: Added a new property `dataproc:pypi.repository` to customize the PyPI repository used for pip. The value can be a URL, or `google` to use a Google-hosted cache of PyPI, accessible without public internet connectivity. Starting in image version 3.1, `google` will be the default; to opt out and return to public PyPI, use the value `pypi`.

summary.title: Customize PyPI Repository for Pip
summary.summary: You can now specify a custom PyPI repository URL or use a Google-hosted cache for pip installations. Starting with image version 3.1, the Google-hosted cache is the default. To revert to the public PyPI, set the value to `pypi`.

summary.title: New serverless Spark versions available
summary.summary: New versions of the serverless runtime for Apache Spark are now available. These include updates to the 1.2, 2.2, and 2.3 release lines. You can find more details on the latest versions in the documentation.

summary.title: New Dataproc image versions available
summary.summary: New subminor image versions for Dataproc on Compute Engine are now available, offering expanded options for your big data workloads. Note that certain versions within the 2.2 and 2.3 releases have been blocklisted.

2025-12-04.content:
**Serverless for Apache Spark:** Runtime version [3.0](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/versioning/dataproc-release-3.0) is now generally available. This version simplifies onboarding, improves reliability, reduces startup latency, and adds support for Spark 4.0.

* Features and improvements:

  + Regional and multi-zonal workloads are used by default to increase obtainability of compute resources
  + Faster startup than previous runtimes
  + Fast resource cleanup that allows faster release of VPC IPs after workload completion
  + End-user credentials are used for all workloads by default
  + New `bigquery` Spark catalog, pre-configured for out-of-the-box BigQuery
    native table interactions
  + New Spark Serverless-specific IAM roles
  + New `dataproc-rm.googleapis.com` API enablement is required

summary.title: Apache Spark 3.0 Now Available
summary.summary: Serverless for Apache Spark version 3.0 is now generally available, offering improved reliability, faster startup times, and support for Spark 4.0. This new version simplifies onboarding and enhances resource management.

2025-11-22.content:

* Updated to `3.0.15` in image version `2.2.71`.
* Updated to `hadoop3-2.2.30` in image versions `2.1.103` and `2.0.154`.

`iceberg`, and `delta-lake` from a Serverless for Apache Spark runtime.

summary.title: New Dataproc image versions available
summary.summary: New image versions for Dataproc on Compute Engine have been released, including updates for 2.0, 2.1, 2.2, and 2.3 series. These updates provide the latest features and security patches for your data processing workloads.

2025-10-22.content:
Announcing the General Availability (GA) of [Lightning Engine for Google Cloud Serverless for Apache Spark](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc-serverless/docs/guides/lightning-engine). Lightning Engine is a [high-performance query accelerator](https://cloud.google.com/blog/products/data-analytics/introducing-lightning-engine-for-apache-spark) that delivers up to 4.3x faster performance for Spark workloads compared to open-source Spark, as measured on TPC-H-like benchmarks.

For more details on enabling Lightning Engine and its advanced features like Native Query Execution (NQE), see [the official documentation](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc-serverless/docs/guides/lightning-engine).

summary.title: Lightning Engine for Apache Spark is now generally available
summary.summary: Lightning Engine for Apache Spark is now generally available, offering significant performance improvements for Spark workloads.

2025-10-22.content:
**Serverless for Apache Spark:** With the Lightning Engine GA release, the property to enable [Native Query Execution (NQE) feature](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc-serverless/docs/guides/lightning-engine#native_query_execution) has been updated.

In order to use Lightning Engine, submit your jobs in the Premium tier. Under Lightning Engine, if you would like to use the NQE feature, set the new flag: [`spark.dataproc.lightningEngine.runtime=native`](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc-serverless/docs/concepts/properties#engine_and_runtime_properties). Users are encouraged to try this feature to explore the full potential of Lightning Engine.

For backward compatibility, the legacy property that was used to enable NQE `spark.dataproc.runtimeEngine=native` will continue to be honored in the existing runtimes 1.2, 2.2 and 2.3, but it's not supported in future releases (3.0+ runtimes).

summary.title: Native Query Execution (NQE) feature updated
summary.summary: The property to enable the Native Query Execution (NQE) feature for the Serverless for Apache Spark has been updated with the Lightning Engine GA release. To use this feature, submit your jobs in the Premium tier and set the new flag: `spark.dataproc.lightningEngine.runtime=native`.

2025-10-13.content: **Serverless for Apache Spark:** Runtimes rollout with Apache Spark upgrade to version [3.5.3](https://spark.apache.org/releases/spark-release-3-5-3.html) in the latest [1.2](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc-serverless/docs/concepts/versions/spark-runtime-1.2) and [2.2](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc-serverless/docs/concepts/versions/spark-runtime-2.2) Serverless for Apache Spark runtime versions has started and is expected to finish by October 16th.

summary.title: Apache Spark Runtimes Rollout
summary.summary: New runtimes with Apache Spark 3.5.3 are rolling out for Serverless for Apache Spark. The upgrade is expected to finish by October 16th.

2025-10-06.content:
**Dataproc on Compute Engine:** The following diagnostic properties are now enabled by default for new Dataproc clusters created with **2.0+** image versions:

* `dataproc:diagnostic.capture.enabled`: Collects [checkpoint diagnostic data](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/support/diagnose-clusters#checkpoint_diagnostic_data) in the cluster [temp bucket](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/configuring-clusters/staging-bucket).
* `dataproc:dataproc.logging.extended.enabled`: Collects logs for the [Knox, Zeppelin, Ranger-usersync, Jupyter\_notebook, Jupyter\_kernel\_gateway components](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/components/overview) and the [Spark History-Server](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/jobs/history-server) in [Cloud Logging](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/guides/logging#cluster-logs).
* `dataproc:dataproc.logging.syslog.enabled`: Collects VM syslogs in [Cloud Logging](https://docs.cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/guides/logging#cluster-logs).

**Note:** To disable any of these features, set the corresponding property to `false` during cluster creation.

To continue using the [Ops Agent](https://docs.cloud.google.com/stackdriver/docs/solutions/agents/ops-agent) initialization action [`opsagent.sh`](https://github.com/GoogleCloudDataproc/initialization-actions/blob/main/opsagent/opsagent.sh) to ingest syslogs from Dataproc cluster nodes, do one of the following:

* **Recommended:** Use [`opsagent_nosyslog.sh`](https://github.com/GoogleCloudDataproc/initialization-actions/blob/main/opsagent/opsagent_nosyslog.sh) since
  VM syslogs are emitted by default from Dataproc clusters.
* Set the `dataproc:dataproc.logging.syslog.enabled=false` and continue using [`opsagent.sh`](https://github.com/GoogleCloudDataproc/initialization-actions/blob/main/opsagent/opsagent.sh)
  to ingest syslogs.

summary.title: New diagnostic properties enabled for Dataproc clusters
summary.summary: New Dataproc clusters (2.0+) now have diagnostic data capture and extended logging enabled by default. This includes checkpoint data, logs for various components and Spark History-Server, and VM syslogs, all of which are sent to Cloud Logging. You can disable these features or adjust the Ops Agent initialization action as needed.

2025-08-12.content: **Dataproc on Compute Engine: Image versions `2.2` and `2.3`**: The [Iceberg optional component](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/components/iceberg) supports the BigLake Iceberg REST catalog.

summary.title: Dataproc Iceberg Support
summary.summary: Dataproc on Compute Engine now supports Iceberg optional component with BigLake Iceberg REST catalog for versions 2.2 and 2.3.

2025-08-12.content: **Dataproc on Compute Engine**: **[Sharing checkpoint diagnostic data:](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/support/diagnose-clusters#enable_and_share_checkpoint_diagnostic_data)** Setting the [`dataproc:diagnostic.capture.access=GOOGLE_DATAPROC_DIAGNOSE`](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/configuring-clusters/cluster-properties#dataproc_service_properties_table) property during cluster creation shares all of the [temp bucket](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/configuring-clusters/staging-bucket) contents with Google Cloud support if [uniform bucket-level access](https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/uniform-bucket-level-access) is enabled on temp bucket. If object-level access control is in effect on the temp bucket, only the [checkpoint diagnostic data folder](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/support/diagnose-clusters#checkpoint_data_location) corresponding to the cluster in Cloud Storage is shared.

summary.title: Dataproc diagnostic data sharing
summary.summary: Share checkpoint diagnostic data with Google Cloud support.

New [Dataproc on Compute Engine subminor image versions](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/versioning/dataproc-version-clusters):

2025-07-15.content:
**Dataproc on Compute Engine:** Starting August 18, 2025, the following diagnostic properties will be enabled by default for newly created Dataproc clusters:

* `dataproc:diagnostic.capture.enabled`: Enables the collection of [checkpoint data](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/support/diagnose-clusters#checkpoint_data) in the cluster [temp bucket](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/configuring-clusters/staging-bucket).
* `dataproc:dataproc.logging.extended.enabled`: Enables the collection of logs for the [Knox, Zeppelin, Ranger-usersync, Jupyter\_notebook, Jupyter\_kernel\_gateway components](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/components/overview) and the [Spark History-Server](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/jobs/history-server) in [Cloud Logging](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/guides/logging#cluster_logs_in).
* `dataproc:dataproc.logging.syslog.enabled`: Enables the collection of VM syslogs in [Cloud Logging](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/guides/logging#cluster_logs_in).

  To continue using the [Ops Agent](https://cloud.google.com/stackdriver/docs/solutions/agents/ops-agent) initialization action [`opsagent.sh`](https://github.com/GoogleCloudDataproc/initialization-actions/blob/main/opsagent/opsagent.sh) to ingest syslogs from Dataproc cluster nodes, do one of the following:

  + Recommended: Use [`opsagent_nosyslog.sh`](https://github.com/GoogleCloudDataproc/initialization-actions/blob/main/opsagent/opsagent_nosyslog.sh) since
    VM syslogs will now be emitted by default from Dataproc clusters.
  + Set the `dataproc:dataproc.logging.syslog.enabled=false` and continue using [`opsagent.sh`](https://github.com/GoogleCloudDataproc/initialization-actions/blob/main/opsagent/opsagent.sh)
    to ingest syslogs.

**Note:** To disable any of these features, set the corresponding property to `false` during cluster creation.

summary.title: Enhanced Diagnostic Data Collection for Dataproc Clusters
summary.summary: Diagnostic data collection will be enabled by default for new Dataproc clusters starting August 18, 2025. This includes checkpoint data, extended logs for components like Spark History-Server, and VM syslogs in Cloud Logging. If you use the Ops Agent initialization action, consider using `opsagent_nosyslog.sh` or disabling the syslog property to avoid duplicate logs.

New [Dataproc on Compute Engine subminor image versions](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/versioning/dataproc-version-clusters):

The `2.3.6-ml-ubuntu22` image extends the 2.3 base image with [ML-specific libraries](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/versioning/dataproc-release-2.3#image_version_23_machine_learning_ml_components).

2025-07-15.content: Dataproc now allows Dynamic update of [multi-tenancy clusters](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/iam/sa-multi-tenancy#create_a_secure_multi-tenancy_cluster).

summary.title: Dataproc Dataproc Dynamic Update for Multi-Tenancy Clusters
summary.summary: You can now dynamically update your multi-tenancy clusters in Dataproc.

2025-07-07.content: The [Cluster Scheduled Stop](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/configuring-clusters/scheduled-stop) feature is available in [preview](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages). You can use this feature to stop clusters after a specified idle period, at a specified future time, or after a specified period from the cluster creation or update request.

summary.title: Dataproc Scheduled Stop Feature Now in Preview
summary.summary: You can now stop your Dataproc clusters automatically after a specified idle period, at a specific time, or after a certain period from creation or update.

New [Dataproc on Compute Engine subminor image versions](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/versioning/dataproc-version-clusters):

The `2.3.5-ml-ubuntu22` image extends the 2.3 base image with [ML-specific libraries](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/versioning/dataproc-release-2.3#image_version_23_machine_learning_ml_components).

2025-07-04.content: [**Serverless for Apache Spark**](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc-serverless/docs) (formerly known as **Dataproc Serverless for Spark**) now supports [OS Login organization policy](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/oslogin/manage-oslogin-in-an-org#set-org-policy). Organizations, folders, and projects that enforce the OS Login policy can now use Serverless for Apache Spark.

summary.title: Serverless for Apache Spark supports OS Login
summary.summary: Serverless for Apache Spark now supports the OS Login organization policy, allowing organizations to use it even when this policy is enforced.

2025-06-20.content: **Dataproc on Compute Engine:** Upgraded the Cloud Storage connector version to `2.2.28` in the latest `2.0` and `2.1` images.

summary.title: Dataproc: Cloud Storage Connector Updated
summary.summary: The Cloud Storage connector version for Dataproc on Compute Engine has been updated to 2.2.28 in the 2.0 and 2.1 images.

2025-06-20.content: **Dataproc on Compute Engine:** Dataproc now automatically configures Knox Gateway configuration properties `gateway.dispatch.whitelist.services` and `gateway.dispatch.whitelist` for component web UIs within the cluster.

summary.title: Dataproc Auto-configures Knox Gateway
summary.summary: Dataproc on Compute Engine now automatically configures Knox Gateway properties for component web UIs, simplifying cluster management.

2025-06-20.content:
**Dataproc on Compute Engine:** Fixed a bug in `trino-jvm cluster properties`. To configure Trino JVM options prefixed with `trino-jvm`, follow these guidelines:

* Configure JVM options starting with `-XX:`, without `:`. For JVM flags without a value, add `=` at the end. For example, add `trino-jvm:-XX+HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError=` as -`XX:+HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError` in the `jvm.config`.
* Specify JVM options system properties with a `-D` prefix the same way. For example, `trino-jvm:-Dsystem.property.name=value`.
* Any value containing `:` cannot be provided as a cluster property.

summary.title: Dataproc: Trino JVM properties configuration fixed
summary.summary: A bug in `trino-jvm cluster properties` for Dataproc on Compute Engine has been fixed. The guidelines for configuring Trino JVM options have been updated to ensure proper formatting for JVM flags and system properties.

2025-06-20.content: **Dataproc on Compute Engine & Dataproc Serverless:** Backported [GH-3198](https://github.com/apache/parquet-java/pull/3199) in Parquet addressing [CVE-2025-46762](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/cve-2025-46762).

summary.title: Parquet security vulnerability fixed in Dataproc
summary.summary: A security vulnerability in Parquet (CVE-2025-46762) has been fixed and backported for Dataproc on Compute Engine and Dataproc Serverless. This update addresses the identified issue.

summary.title: Dataproc Serverless for Spark Runtime Update
summary.summary: New versions of Dataproc Serverless for Spark runtime are now available: 1.1.108, 1.2.52, 2.2.52, and 2.3.3.

2025-06-09.content:
Announcing the GA release of [Dataproc on Compute Engine image version 2.3](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/versioning/dataproc-release-2.3):

Image Version 2.3 is a lightweight image that contains only core components, reducing exposure to Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs). For higher security compliance requirements, use the image version 2.3 or later when creating a Dataproc cluster. Optional components can still be deployed on-demand.

The following images are the latest available `2.3` subminor image versions:

* `2.3.3-debian12`, `2.3.3-rocky9`, and `2.3.3-ubuntu22`

`2.3` images include the components listed in [2.3.x release versions](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/versioning/dataproc-release-2.3).

summary.title: Dataproc on Compute Engine 2.3 Now Generally Available
summary.summary: Google Cloud announces the general availability of Dataproc on Compute Engine image version 2.3. This version is a lightweight image with core components, enhancing security by reducing exposure to CVEs. It is recommended for clusters with high security compliance requirements, and optional components can be deployed as needed. The latest subminor versions available are 2.3.3 with Debian 12, Rocky 9, and Ubuntu 22.

summary.title: Dataproc Serverless for Spark runtime updates
summary.summary: New runtime versions are available for Dataproc Serverless for Spark. The updated versions include 1.1.107, 1.2.51, 2.2.51, and 2.3.2.

2025-06-06.content: **Dataproc Serverless for Spark:** Fixed a bug that prevented the `spark.executorEnv` property from correctly setting specific executor environment variables across all runtimes.

summary.title: Dataproc Serverless: Executor environment variable bug fixed
summary.summary: A bug that affected the setting of specific executor environment variables in Dataproc Serverless for Spark has been resolved. The fix ensures that the `spark.executorEnv` property now functions correctly across all runtimes.

2025-06-01.content:
New [Dataproc on Compute Engine subminor image versions](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/concepts/versioning/dataproc-version-clusters#supported_dataproc_versions):

* 2.0.143-debian10, 2.0.143-rocky8, 2.0.143-ubuntu18
* 2.1.91-debian11, 2.1.90-rocky8, 2.1.91-ubuntu20, 2.1.91-ubuntu20-arm
* 2.2.59-debian12, 2.2.59-rocky9, 2.2.59-ubuntu22

summary.title: New Dataproc Image Versions Released
summary.summary: New Dataproc image versions are available for Compute Engine, including updates to the 2.0, 2.1, and 2.2 series. These new versions support Debian 10/11/12, Rocky 8/9, and Ubuntu 18/20/22 operating systems, with some offering ARM compatibility.

2025-06-01.content: **Dataproc on Compute Engine**: Fixed the ordering of log entries generated from clusters created with `2.2+` image versions by assigning timestamps closer to the log generation time.

summary.title: Fixed log entry ordering in Dataproc
summary.summary: Timestamps for log entries from Dataproc on Compute Engine clusters with '2.2+' image versions have been corrected to more accurately reflect log generation time.

summary.title: Dataproc Serverless for Spark Runtime Updates
summary.summary: New runtime versions are available for Dataproc Serverless for Spark, including 1.1.106, 1.2.50, 2.2.50, and 2.3.1.

2025-05-30.content:
The support dates for **Dataproc on Compute Engine** image versions `2.0`, `2.1`, and `2.2` have been extended, as follows:

* Image version `2.2`: Supported until 03/31/2027
* Image version `2.1`: Supported until 03/31/2026
* Image version `2.0` Supported until 09/30/2025

summary.title: Dataproc image version support extended
summary.summary: The support periods for Dataproc on Compute Engine image versions 2.0, 2.1, and 2.2 have been extended. Version 2.2 is now supported until March 31, 2027, version 2.1 until March 31, 2026, and version 2.0 until September 30, 2025.

2025-05-28.content: Announcing the [General Availability](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages) release of **Spark on BigQuery**, which lets you create a serverless Spark session in a [BigQuery Studio](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/query-overview#bigquery-studio) notebook. Use this feature to create, run, and test Spark jobs quickly and easily. For more information, see [Run PySpark code in BigQuery Studio notebooks](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/docs/use-spark).

summary.title: Spark on BigQuery Now Generally Available
summary.summary: We are excited to announce the general availability of Spark on BigQuery. This new feature allows you to create and run serverless Spark sessions directly within BigQuery Studio notebooks, making it easier than ever to develop and test your Spark jobs.

summary.title: Dataproc Serverless Spark Runtime Updates
summary.summary: New runtime versions for Dataproc Serverless for Spark are now available: 1.1.105, 1.2.49, 2.2.49, and 2.3.0.

2025-05-28.content:
Announcing the [General Availability (GA)](https://cloud.google.com/products#product-launch-stages) release of Dataproc Serverless for Spark runtime versions [2.3](https://cloud.google.com/dataproc-serverless/docs/concepts/versions/spark-runtime-versions#spark_runtime_version_23), which include the following components:

* Spark 3.5.1
* BigQuery Spark Connector 0.42.3
* Cloud Storage Connector 3.1.2
* Java 17
* Python 3.11
* R 4.3
* Scala 2.13

summary.title: Dataproc Serverless for Spark Now Generally Available
summary.summary: Dataproc Serverless for Spark is now generally available with runtime version 2.3, featuring Spark 3.5.1, BigQuery Spark Connector 0.42.3, Cloud Storage Connector 3.1.2, Java 17, Python 3.11, R 4.3, and Scala 2.13.
